required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prevalence of Liver Disease in Patients Dependent on Parenteral Nutrition
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Prevalence Study in Adolescent and Adult Patients Dependent on Parenteral Nutrition to Assess the Incidence of Intestinal Failure-Associated Liver Disease

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a multi-center prospective cross-sectional observational study that will assess the prevalence of liver disease in patients dependent on parenteral nutrition (PN) for 4 or more days per week, for the past 6 months or longer. Liver disease will be determined by the presence of choline deficiency, cholestasis (confirmed by elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) liver isoenzyme level), and steatosis (confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging-derived proton density fat fraction (MRI-PDFF).
The objective of this study is to investigate the presence/prevalence of liver disease in patients dependent on PN (≥4 days a week) for 6 months or longer.

detailed_description.textblock:
Eligible participants will provide blood samples at Visit 1 to determine choline deficiency, elevated serum ALP liver isoenzyme level and liver dysfunction. Only participants diagnosed as having choline deficiency and elevated serum ALP liver isoenzyme level will be requested to return for a second clinic visit for imaging (MRI-PDFF).
The purpose of this study is to understand and document critical epidemiological data related to choline deficiency and the incidence of liver disease in patients dependent on PN (≥ 4 days a week) for 6 months or longer and to better understand this patient population to help determine who might benefit from innovative treatments including IV Choline Chloride treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of patients with choline deficiency
primary_outcome.description: Choline deficiency is defined as plasma-free choline concentration less than 7 nmol/mL.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of patients with choline deficiency and elevated serum ALP liver isoenzyme level
primary_outcome.description: Choline deficiency is defined as plasma-free choline concentration less than 7 nmol/mL. Elevated serum ALP liver isoenzyme level is defined as >1.5x upper limit of normal.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of patients with choline deficiency, elevated serum ALP liver isoenzyme level and MRI-PDFF >7%
primary_outcome.description: Choline deficiency is defined as plasma-free choline concentration less than 7 nmol/mL. Elevated serum ALP liver isoenzyme level is defined as >1.5x upper limit of normal. MRI-PDFF >7 %

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of patients with choline deficiency and abnormal liver tests including serum direct bilirubin, AST, ALT and GGT
secondary_outcome.description: Choline deficiency is defined as plasma-free choline concentration less than 7 nmol/mL; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; ALT = alanine transaminase; GGT = gamma-glutamyl transferase.

study_pop.textblock: This study will include adults and adolescent participants 12 years and older dependent on PN (≥ 4 days a week) for 6 months or longer, in the primary care clinic setting.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The participant and/or their parent/Legally Authorized Representative is willing and able to provide signed informed consent or assent as appropriate
- Male or female adults 18 to 80 years of age, or adolescents age 12 to 17 years
- Dependent on parenteral nutrition, defined as receiving PN ≥ 4 days a week for 6 months or longer prior to screening to meet nutritional, caloric, fluid, and/or electrolyte needs
- The Investigator expects no changes in the lipid, dextrose, amino acid, or vitamin regimen to be medically necessary during the participant's participation in the study
- Willingness of participant to maintain his/her current habitual oral diet and fluids regimen for the study duration
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants taking steatogenic medications for ≥12 weeks in the past 12 months (e.g., amiodarone, tamoxifen, methotrexate, tetracycline, glucocorticoids, anabolic steroids, over the usual dose of estrogen for hormone replacement therapy, and valproate); those taking any medicine (e.g., metformin, thiazolidinediones, ursodeoxycholic acid, pentoxifylline, S-adenosyl-L-Methionine, and betaine) that could affect the measurement of IFALD within 12 weeks prior to study entry
- Participants taking potential hepatotoxic medications that in the judgement of the Investigator is causing hepatic abnormalities
- Participants with a cardiac pacemaker, intravascular stents, other metallic devices, and claustrophobia which are contraindicated to magnetic resonance imaging
- Participants who took choline supplements or choline-containing multivitamins within 14 days of screening
- History of major organ transplant (e.g., heart, kidney, liver, etc.)
For more information on eligibility criteria, please contact the sponsor.
